Computing metric hulls in graphs

Kolja Knauer Aix Marseille Univ, UniversitÃ© de Toulon, CNRS, LIS, Marseille, France kolja.knauer@lis-lab.fr Â andÂ  Nicolas Nisse UniversitÃ© CÃ´te dâ€™Azur, Inria, CNRS, I3S, France nicolas.nisse@inria.fr
Abstract.

We prove that, given a closure function the smallest preimage of a closed set can be calculated in polynomial time in the number of closed sets. This implies that there is a polynomial time algorithm to compute the convex hull-number of a graph, when all its convex subgraphs are given as input. We then show that computing if the smallest preimage of a closed set is logarithmic in the size of the ground set is LOGSNP-complete if only the ground set is given. A special instance of this problem is computing the dimension of a poset given its linear extension graph, that was conjectured to be in P.

The intent to show that the latter problem is LOGSNP-complete leads to several interesting questions and to the definition of the isometric hull, i.e., a smallest isometric subgraph containing a given set of vertices Sğ‘†S. While for |S|=2ğ‘†2|S|=2 an isometric hull is just a shortest path, we show that computing the isometric hull of a set of vertices is NP-complete even if |S|=3ğ‘†3|S|=3. Finally, we consider the problem of computing the isometric hull-number of a graph and show that computing it is Î£2PsubscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘ƒ2\Sigma^{P}_{2} complete.

A (convex) hull set of GğºG is a set SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V such that convâ€‹(S)=Vconvğ‘†ğ‘‰\mathrm{conv}(S)=V. The hull-number hâ€‹nâ€‹(G)â„ğ‘›ğºhn(G) of GğºG is the size of a minimum hull set of GğºG. The hull-number was introduced inÂ [13], and since then has been the object of numerous papers, in particular because this may model contamination spreading processes. Most of the results on the hull number are about computing good bounds for specific graph classes, see e.g.Â [9, 16, 7, 6, 12, 8].

While computing the convex hull of a set vertices can be done in polynomial time, computing the hull-number of a graph GğºG is known to be NP-completeÂ [11] and remains so even if GğºG is a bipartite graphÂ [2] or moreover a partial cubeÂ [1], i.e., an isometric subgraph of a hypercube. It is well-known, that the function conv:2Vâ†’2V:convâ†’superscript2ğ‘‰superscript2ğ‘‰\mathrm{conv}:2^{V}\to 2^{V} is a closure, where generally a function câ€‹l:2Aâ†’2A:ğ‘ğ‘™â†’superscript2ğ´superscript2ğ´cl:2^{A}\to 2^{A}, is called closure if it satisfies the following conditions for all sets X,YâŠ†Ağ‘‹ğ‘Œğ´X,Y\subseteq A

This leads to the following generalization of the hull-number of a graph, that we call Minimum Generator Set (MGS):

Pseudo-closures embody a large class of objects. In particular, closures are essentially the same as lattices (see the discussion above QuestionÂ 2.9). Thus, deciding whether for an element â„“â„“\ell in a lattice Lğ¿L there are kğ‘˜k join-irreducibles, whose join is â„“â„“\ell, can be done in polynomial time. Lattices encode many combinatorial objects (for the cases below seeÂ [17, 20]). Thus, our results for instance yield polynomial time algorithms to decide whether:

  • â€¢

Given a set Ağ´A, a polytime computable atomistic closure câ€‹l:2Aâ†’2A:ğ‘ğ‘™â†’superscript2ğ´superscript2ğ´cl:2^{A}\to 2^{A} and an integer kâ‰¤logâ¡(|A|)ğ‘˜ğ´k\leq\log(|A|), is there a set XâŠ†Ağ‘‹ğ´X\subseteq A with |X|â‰¤kğ‘‹ğ‘˜|X|\leq k such that câ€‹lâ€‹(X)=Ağ‘ğ‘™ğ‘‹ğ´cl(X)=A?

Whether the corresponding results hold for the hull-number of a graph is open. In particular, inÂ [1] it was conjectured that given a poset together with all its linear extensions, its dimension can be computed in polynomial time. Moreover, it was shown this problem is an instance of LOGHULL-NUMBER for partial cubes. While trying to establish a reduction to the hull-number problem for partial cubes, in order to show that LOGHULL-NUMBER for partial cubes is LOGSNP-complete, we arrive at the second metric hull-problem of concern in this paper, which to our knowledge is a novel problem: Let again G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) be a graph. A set SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V is isometric if, for any u,vâˆˆSğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘†u,v\in S, a (u,v)ğ‘¢ğ‘£(u,v)-shortest path if GğºG is included in Sğ‘†S. An isometric hull isoâ€‹(S)isoğ‘†\mathrm{iso}(S) of a set SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V is a smallest isometric set containing Sğ‘†S. Thus, this problem can be seen as a variation of the Steiner Tree problems. In particular, an isometric hull of two vertices is simply a shortest path. An isometric hull set of GğºG is a set SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V such that isoâ€‹(S)=Visoğ‘†ğ‘‰\mathrm{iso}(S)=V. The isometric hull-number iâ€‹hâ€‹nâ€‹(G)ğ‘–â„ğ‘›ğºihn(G) of GğºG is the size of a minimum isometric hull set of GğºG. In SectionÂ 3 we show that computing an isometric hull of a set of vertices Sğ‘†S is NP-complete even if |S|=3ğ‘†3|S|=3 (TheoremÂ 3.1) and that computing the isometric hull-number of a graph is Î£2PsubscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘ƒ2\Sigma^{P}_{2} complete (TheoremÂ 3.2).

2. Minimum generators of pseudo-closures

In particular, pseudo-closures generalize closures in a different way than preclosures, which are not required to be idempotent. Let us first argue that in a way pseudo-closures are closures without the property of being extensive.

Lemma 2.1.

Let f:2Aâ†’2A:ğ‘“â†’superscript2ğ´superscript2ğ´f:2^{A}\rightarrow 2^{A}. The following are equivalent:

  • (i)

    fğ‘“f is a closure,

  • (ii)

    fğ‘“f is an extensive pseudo-closure,

  • (iii)

    fğ‘“f is an extensive and size-increasing pseudo-closure.

Proof.

(i)âŸ¹\implies(iii): Let fğ‘“f be a closure, then it is extensive and increasing by definition and clearly also size-increasing. Since fâ€‹(X)âŠ†fâ€‹(XâˆªY)ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œf(X)\subseteq f(X\cup Y) and fâ€‹(Y)âŠ†fâ€‹(XâˆªY)ğ‘“ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œf(Y)\subseteq f(X\cup Y), then fâ€‹(X)âˆªfâ€‹(Y)âŠ†fâ€‹(XâˆªY)ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œf(X)\cup f(Y)\subseteq f(X\cup Y). Hence, fâ€‹(fâ€‹(X)âˆªfâ€‹(Y))âŠ†fâ€‹(fâ€‹(XâˆªY))=fâ€‹(XâˆªY)ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œf(f(X)\cup f(Y))\subseteq f(f(X\cup Y))=f(X\cup Y). Therefore fğ‘“f is an extensive and size-increasing pseudo-closure.

(iii)âŸ¹\implies(ii): trivial.

(ii)âŸ¹\implies(i): Let fğ‘“f be an extensive pseudo-closure. As argued above fğ‘“f is idempotent. It remains to prove that fğ‘“f is increasing. Let XâŠ†Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX\subseteq Y. We have

fâ€‹(X)âŠ†fâ€‹(X)âˆªfâ€‹(Y)âŠ†fâ€‹(fâ€‹(X)âˆªfâ€‹(Y))=fâ€‹(XâˆªY)=fâ€‹(Y),ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘Œf(X)\subseteq f(X)\cup f(Y)\subseteq f(f(X)\cup f(Y))=f(X\cup Y)=f(Y),

where the second inclusion uses that fğ‘“f is extensive and the first equality uses that fğ‘“f is a pseudo-closure.

From Th.Â 2.3, LemmaÂ 2.1, and the preceding discussion we immediately get:

Corollary 2.4.

This confirms a conjecture ofÂ [1] (which could have probably also been extracted fromÂ [18]) and slightly improves the time-complexity ofÂ [18] in the case of a closure. 2.2. Generating with small input

In this section we show that for an atomistic closure câ€‹l:2Aâ†’2A:ğ‘ğ‘™â†’superscript2ğ´superscript2ğ´cl:2^{A}\to 2^{A}, the problem MGS is W[2]-complete with respect to the size of the solution, when only Ağ´A is the input. Furthermore, LOGMGS is LOGSNP-complete. We then introduce the problem COORDINATE REVERSAL, show an equivalence with HITTING SET, and finally relate it to the hull-number problem in partial cubes.

For us, the optimization problem DOMINATING SET consists in given a directed graph D=(V,A)ğ·ğ‘‰ğ´D=(V,A) to find the minimum kğ‘˜k, such that there is XâŠ†Vğ‘‹ğ‘‰X\subseteq V with |X|=kğ‘‹ğ‘˜|X|=k and every vâˆˆVâˆ–Xğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘‹v\in V\setminus X has an incoming arc from a vertex in Xğ‘‹X.

Proposition 2.5.

MGS and DOMINATING SET are L-equivalent, i.e., there are polynomial reductions both ways that preserve optimal solutions.

Proof.

Given a directed graph D=(V,A)ğ·ğ‘‰ğ´D=(V,A) we construct an atomistic closure câ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™cl such that a minimum dominating set of Dğ·D is of the same size as a minimum generating set of câ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™cl. First, we can assume that the collection of closed in-neighborhoods {NÂ¯âˆ’â€‹(v)âˆ£vâˆˆV}conditional-setsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‰\{\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\} is a set without inclusions, since dominating set is L-equivalent to hitting set on (V,{NÂ¯âˆ’â€‹(v)âˆ£vâˆˆV})ğ‘‰conditional-setsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‰(V,\{\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\}). For the same reason, we may assume that for any two vertices u,vâˆˆVğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘‰u,v\in V there is a set in closed in-neighborhood containing uğ‘¢u but not vğ‘£v. We define câ€‹l:2Vâ†’2V:ğ‘ğ‘™â†’superscript2ğ‘‰superscript2ğ‘‰cl:2^{V}\rightarrow 2^{V} by setting the closed sets to be all possible intersections of the complements of closed in-neighborhoods {Vâˆ–NÂ¯âˆ’â€‹(v)âˆ£vâˆˆV}conditional-setğ‘‰superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‰\{V\setminus\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\}, i.e., câ€‹lâ€‹(X)ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘‹cl(X) is the smallest set of vertices containing Xğ‘‹X which can be expressed as intersection of {Vâˆ–NÂ¯âˆ’â€‹(v)âˆ£vâˆˆV}conditional-setğ‘‰superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‰\{V\setminus\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\}. It is easy to check that câ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™cl is a closure and since for any two vertices u,vâˆˆVğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘‰u,v\in V there is a set in closed in-neighborhood containing uğ‘¢u but not vğ‘£v, we have câ€‹lâ€‹({v})={v}ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘£ğ‘£cl(\{v\})=\{v\} for all vâˆˆVğ‘£ğ‘‰v\in V, i.e., câ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™cl is atomistic. Clearly, câ€‹lâ€‹(X)ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘‹cl(X) can be computed in polynomial time for a given XâŠ†Vğ‘‹ğ‘‰X\subseteq V.

Now, a dominating set XâŠ†Vğ‘‹ğ‘‰X\subseteq V corresponds to a hitting set of {NÂ¯âˆ’â€‹(v)âˆ£vâˆˆV}conditional-setsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‰\{\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\} which in turn is a set of elements not contained in any of the maximal proper closed sets of câ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™cl, i.e., câ€‹lâ€‹(X)=Vğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘‹ğ‘‰cl(X)=V. This construction is clearly reversible, so we have proved the claim.âˆ

While it was known before that determining the hull-number of graphs, bipartite graphs, and even partial cubes is NP-complete, the known reductions reduce variants of 3-SAT to the decision version of hull-number. Here, we have shown that two decision versions of combinatorial optimization problems are equivalent in the stronger sense of L-reductions, i.e., sizes of solutions are preserved. This has some immediate consequences.

Since DOMINATING SET is W[2]-complete, PropositionÂ 2.5 gives:

Corollary 2.6.

MGS is W[2]-complete.

Using results of Dinur and SteurerÂ [10], by PropositionÂ 2.5 we get:

Corollary 2.7.

MGS cannot be approximated to (1âˆ’oâ€‹(1))â‹…lnâ¡nâ‹…1o1n\bigl{(}1-o(1)\bigr{)}\cdot\ln{n} unless P=NP.

InÂ [19] it is shown that LOGDOMINATING SET is LOGSNP (aka LOG[2]) complete, which with PropositionÂ 2.5 gives:

Corollary 2.8.

LOGMGS is LOGSNP-complete.

Since the convconv\mathrm{conv}-operator for graphs is an atomistic closure, we wonder if similar results can be proved for the hull-number problem, or if this problem is essentially easier. For instance inÂ [3], a fixed parameter tractable algorithm to compute the hull-number of any graph was obtained. But there the parameter is the size of a vertex cover. How about the complexity when parameterized by the size of a solution?

It is well-known that closures correspond to lattices in the following way: Given a closure câ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™cl define the inclusion order on the closed sets, i.e., Imâ€‹(câ€‹l)Imğ‘ğ‘™\mathrm{Im}(cl). Since this order has a unique maximal element Ağ´A and the intersection of closed sets is closed, it is a lattice. On the other hand given a lattice Lğ¿L with set Jğ½J of join-irreducibles associate to every â„“âˆˆLâ„“ğ¿\ell\in L the set Jâ„“subscriptğ½â„“J_{\ell} of join-irreducibles that are less or equal than â„“â„“\ell. Now, Lğ¿L is the inclusion order on {Jâ„“âˆ£â„“âˆˆL}conditional-setsubscriptğ½â„“â„“ğ¿\{J_{\ell}\mid\ell\in L\}. In turn the latter is the set of closed sets of câ€‹l:2Jâ†’2J:ğ‘ğ‘™â†’superscript2ğ½superscript2ğ½cl:2^{J}\rightarrow 2^{J} defined as Xâ†¦Jâ‹Xmaps-toğ‘‹subscriptğ½ğ‘‹X\mapsto J_{\bigvee X}, where â‹Xğ‘‹\bigvee X denotes the join of Xğ‘‹X. This is easily seen to be a closure. Recall that a lattice is atomistic if all its elements can be generated as joins of atoms. The corresponding class of closures are precisely the atomistic closures. Now we can state the following :

Question 2.9.

What are the atomistic lattices that come from the convex subgraphs of a graph?

Clearly, these lattices are quite special, in particular any such lattice is entirely determined by its first two levels, since these correspond to vertices and edges of the graph. On the other hand, it is not clear what other properties such lattices enjoy. For instance, the graph in FigureÂ 1 shows that convexity lattices of graphs are not graded in general, i.e., not all maximal chains are of the same length.

For example, Ptolemaic graphs are exactly those graphs whose lattice of convex subgraphs is lower locally distributiveÂ [14]. Also, inÂ [1] the lattices of convex subgraphs of partial cubes were characterized. However, we do not know how to make use of this characterization.

Let us now approach the hull-number problem in partial cubes via a different reduction. We call COORDINATE REVERSAL the following problem:

Now, inÂ [1] it is shown that in a partial cube G=(V,E)âŠ†Qdğºğ‘‰ğ¸subscriptğ‘„ğ‘‘G=(V,E)\subseteq Q_{d} HULL-NUMBER coincides with COORDINATE REVERSAL for Vğ‘‰V and Qdsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘‘Q_{d}, therefore, HULL-NUMBER in partial cubes is a special case of COORDINATE REVERSAL. In order to L-reduce COORDINATE REVERSAL to partial cube hull-number along the lines of PropositionÂ 2.10, it would be interesting to check, if given a subset Vâ€²âŠ†Qdsuperscriptğ‘‰â€²subscriptğ‘„ğ‘‘V^{\prime}\subseteq Q_{d} a smallest partial cube containing Vâ€²superscriptğ‘‰â€²V^{\prime} has to be polynomial in |Vâ€²|+dsuperscriptğ‘‰â€²ğ‘‘|V^{\prime}|+d. Moreover it is important to maintain the same solution size with respect to COORDINATE REVERSAL. InÂ [15, Theorem 15.59] it is shown that LOGHITTING SET is LOGSNP (aka LOG[2]) complete. Hence, this would show LOGSNP-completeness of LOGHULL-NUMBER for partial cubes, one instance of which is calculating the dimension of a poset given its linear extensions, seeÂ [1]. So as a first step we wonder:

Question 2.11.

Let Xğ‘‹X be a set of vertices of the hypercube Qdsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘‘Q_{d}, does there exist an isometric subgraph GğºG of Qdsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘‘Q_{d}, containing Xğ‘‹X, such that |G|ğº|G| is polynomial in |X|+dğ‘‹ğ‘‘|X|+d?

Let Mksubscriptğ‘€ğ‘˜M_{k} a (0,1)01(0,1)-matrix whose columns are all the (0,1)01(0,1)-vectors of length kğ‘˜k. Now, XkâŠ†Q2ksubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„superscript2ğ‘˜X_{k}\subseteq Q_{2^{k}} is defined as the set of rows of Mksubscriptğ‘€ğ‘˜M_{k}. We do not know the answer to QuestionÂ 2.11 for the set Xksubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜X_{k}.

These questions lead to the problem of computing a small isometric subgraph containing a given set of vertices, which is the subject of the next section.

3. Isometric hull

We recall the definitions related to the isometric hull from the introduction. Let G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) be a graph. For any v,uâˆˆVğ‘£ğ‘¢ğ‘‰v,u\in V, let distGâ€‹(u,v)subscriptdistğºğ‘¢ğ‘£\mbox{dist}_{G}(u,v) denote the distance between uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v, i.e., the minimum number of edges of a path between uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v in GğºG. A subgraph H=(Vâ€²,Eâ€²)ğ»superscriptğ‘‰â€²superscriptğ¸â€²H=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) (i.e., Vâ€²âŠ†Vsuperscriptğ‘‰â€²ğ‘‰V^{\prime}\subseteq V and Eâ€²âŠ†(Vâ€²Ã—Vâ€²)âˆ©E)E^{\prime}\subseteq(V^{\prime}\times V^{\prime})\cap E)) of GğºG is isometric if distGâ€‹(u,v)=distHâ€‹(u,v)subscriptdistğºğ‘¢ğ‘£subscriptdistğ»ğ‘¢ğ‘£\mbox{dist}_{G}(u,v)=\mbox{dist}_{H}(u,v) for any u,vâˆˆVâ€²ğ‘¢ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‰â€²u,v\in V^{\prime}. Given SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V, an isometric hull of Sğ‘†S is any subgraph H=(Vâ€²,Eâ€²)ğ»superscriptğ‘‰â€²superscriptğ¸â€²H=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) of GğºG such that SâŠ†Vâ€²ğ‘†superscriptğ‘‰â€²S\subseteq V^{\prime} and Hğ»H is isometric. An isometric hull H=(Vâ€²,Eâ€²)ğ»superscriptğ‘‰â€²superscriptğ¸â€²H=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) of Sğ‘†S is minimum if |Vâ€²|superscriptğ‘‰â€²|V^{\prime}| is minimum, i.e., there are no isometric hulls of Sğ‘†S with strictly less vertices. Note that a set Sğ‘†S may have several minimum isometric hulls. As an example, consider the 444-node cycle C4=(a,b,c,d)subscriptğ¶4ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘C_{4}=(a,b,c,d): the subgraphs induced by {a,b,c}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\{a,b,c\} and {a,d,c}ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘\{a,d,c\} are minimum isometric hulls of S={a,c}ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘S=\{a,c\}. More generally, for any S={u,v}ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘£S=\{u,v\}, inclusion-minimal isometric hulls of Sğ‘†S are any shortest path between uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v. So, if |S|=2ğ‘†2|S|=2, all minimal isometric supergraphs of Sğ‘†S are of the same size and computing a minimum isometric hull of Sğ‘†S is easy. For |S|>2ğ‘†2|S|>2 it is easy to find examples with minimal isometric supergraphs that are not minimum. We show below that computing a minimum isometric hull is NP-complete if |S|>2ğ‘†2|S|>2. An isometric-hull set (or simply hull set) SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V of GğºG is any subset of the vertices such that GğºG is the (unique) minimum isometric hull of Sğ‘†S.

This section is devoted to prove the following theorems.

Theorem 3.1.

Given an nğ‘›n-node bipartite graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E), SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V and kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}, deciding whether there exists an isometric hull Hğ»H of Sğ‘†S with |Vâ€‹(H)|â‰¤kğ‘‰ğ»ğ‘˜|V(H)|\leq k is NP-complete, even if |S|=3ğ‘†3|S|=3 and k=nâˆ’1ğ‘˜ğ‘›1k=n-1. In particular, deciding whether a set Sğ‘†S of vertices is a hull set of a graph is coNP-complete.

Theorem 3.2.

Given a graph GğºG and kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}, the problem of deciding whether GğºG admits an isometric-hull set of size at most kğ‘˜k is Î£2subscriptÎ£2\Sigma_{2}-complete.

Let us start with an easier result where neither the size of the input set Sğ‘†S nor the size kğ‘˜k of the isometric hull are constrained, but where the class of bipartite graphs is restricted to have diameter 333.

Claim 2.

Proof of the claim.

Note that deciding whether a set Sğ‘†S of vertices is not a hull set of an nğ‘›n-node graph is equivalent to decide whether Sğ‘†S has an isometric hull of size <nabsentğ‘›<n. Therefore:

Corollary 3.5.

Deciding whether a set of vertices is a hull set is coNP-complete.

Finally, to prove TheoremÂ 3.2, we present a reduction from the problem of satisfiability for quantified Boolean formulas with 222 alternations of quantifiers Qâ€‹Sâ€‹Aâ€‹T2ğ‘„ğ‘†ğ´subscriptğ‘‡2QSAT_{2}. The reduction is an adaptation of the one presented in the proof of TheoremÂ 3.1.

In the proof below, we will use the following easy claim to force some vertices to belong to any hull set.

Proof.

of TheoremÂ 3.2. First, the problem is in Î£2subscriptÎ£2\Sigma_{2}. Indeed, by TheoremÂ 3.1, a certificate Sğ‘†S (i.e., a set of vertices which is supposed to be a hull set of GğºG) can be checked using an NP oracle.

4. Further work

We have devised a polytime algorithm for MGS when all images of a pseudo-closure are given as an input. While pseudo-closures generalize closures, they do not capture other generalizations from the literature such as preclosuresÂ [4] (since they are not idempotent) or closure functions of greedoidsÂ [5] (since they are extensive). Can similar algorithms be provided for these classes?

An open problem with respect to closures is QuestionÂ 2.9, i.e., find a characterization of those closures coming from the convex subgraphs of a graph. The corresponding question for (finite) metric spaces is also open, seeÂ [17]. Moreover, we wonder about the complexity of LOGHULL-NUMBER, even for partial cubes. A particular question arising in this context is, whether HULL-NUMBER admits an FPT algorithm parametrized by solution size kğ‘˜k. Finally, we would like to recall QuestionÂ 2.11, i.e., is there a subset Xğ‘‹X of the hypercube Qdsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘‘Q_{d} such that a smallest partial cube in Qdsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘‘Q_{d} containing Xğ‘‹X is not of polynomial size in d+|X|ğ‘‘ğ‘‹d+|X|?
